content:
This Little Town
Moderated By: Oversoul
Back-Up Mod: Papa Zito
Reviewed By: Regfan, Cogito Ergo Sum, Petroleumjelly

Game Over!


---

The police report stated numerous witnesses saw Jonathan walking down the street only to stop suddenly and stare down into an alleyway. Some witnesses claimed he shouted before entering the alley; others said that he sprinted into the darkness waving his arms erratically perhaps he did both. Regardless of the beginning, the scenarios end with the same conclusion - brief intense flashes of light followed by echoing bangs erupting from the alley pulling the unreliable witnesses out of their drunken stupor and into clarity. Every witness claims they saw no one leave the alley from the direction Jonathan entered. The only noise they heard afterwards were cries of panic and their own frantic footsteps on the pavement. It wasn’t until they had come across Jonathan’s lifeless bullet ridden body did they realize the reason for his fateful detour. A woman’s body lay limp against the wall, her blouse covered in blood. She was shot in the head. The town of Sholle would never be the same.

---

Standard Rules

(adapted from Animorpherv1 and Petroleumjelly)

1.) Be civil.
2.) No talking outside the game about this game, unless your role PM allows otherwise.
3.) No editing or deleting your own posts or another's posts.
4.) No mod-quoting. Only paraphrase in your own words. You may quote from the sample role PM. As a corollary, do not impersonate the Mod.
5.) This is a closed setup, which means the only roles you will know in advance are your own and that of any other player I mention in your role PM. All other role information is secret, including how many players with a certain role exist and even if the role exists in the first place.
6.) Nights will last at least 48 hours to 72 hours, or until a replacement is found. Day One will last at most three weeks. Each other game Day will last at most two weeks. Exigent circumstances may result in an extension.
7.) A lynch (or a No Lynch) takes a majority of votes. In other words, if 7 players are alive, it takes 4 votes to lynch. A majority is half the amount of living players rounded to the nearest whole number. If deadline is reached with no player having enough votes for a lynch, the day ends in an automatic No Lynch.
8.) To vote, post a bolded Vote: Oversoul. To unvote, post a bolded Unvote: Oversoul. Because of the nature of this game, if you want to unvote somebody, you do not have to use a formal Unvote: Oversoul although it is appreciated.
9.) If you have a request, the fastest and preferred way to get ahold of me is by PM'ing me, but you may also communicate to me in thread if it is day or twilight and you are still alive. To do so, bold "Mod (or Oversoul):" followed by what you want to tell me, as in Mod: Please prod Oversoul or Mod: Oversoul should have seven votes, not three. Please use your judgment in whether or not what you want to tell me should be public knowledge before talking to me in the thread. In addition, I will not entertain questions regarding possible night actions, nor will I answer questions about a person's role unless you happen to be the person in question and you ask me privately.
10.) I am not clairvoyant, omnipresent, or perfect. If I miss anything, please let me know in the game thread or through a Private Message.
11.) My colors for this game are this blue (#003366) and and this purple (#331150). Do not use these colors under any circumstances.
12.) If you're dead, you are allowed one "Bah" post after your death. This "Bah" post must contain no information about the game or its contents. Any post after death containing information will be met with strict punishment.
13.) After a lynch is reached, there is a brief period of twilight (from the time of lynch to the time I check the thread). You may talk during twilight, but you must adhere to the game's rules. No more votes will be counted after a lynch has been reached.
14.) Do not use small text, invisible text, spoiler text, etc. All players should be able to read everything you say. As a corollary, do not constantly use CAPS LOCK, large text, colored text, etc. All players should be able to read everything you say without getting a headache.
15.) I will issue a prod to any player that does not post for 72 hours without notifying me of his or her absence. If you are prodded, you will have 48 hours from the time of submission to post in thread. Failure to do so may result in replacement. I will only prod the same player twice after that, he or she must post every 72 hours to ensure that he or she remains in the game.
16.) Discussing an ongoing game gets you a warning the first time and a MODKILL the second time. Claiming to be scum with someone else will result in a modkill.
17.) I reserve the right to change or add to all game rules.
18.) The most important rule of all, saved for last for what I think is a very good reason: HAVE FUN! Enjoy! And good luck!

Sample Role PMs

You are a Vanilla Townie!

Abilities
You do not have any abilities other than your voice and your vote. Use them wisely!

You win when all threats to the town are dead and at least 1 member of the town is alive. Confirm via PM.


You are a Mafia Goon!

Abilities
During the Night, you and your teammates may choose one person to shoot. If successful, the player will die.

During the night, you may talk [url=xxx]here[/url] with your teammates.

Your teammates are: [insert names here]

You win when the mafia outnumbers town and at least 1 mafia member is alive, or nothing can prevent the same. Confirm via PM.

I am now sending out role PMs by numerical order.

The game will open once 8 people have confirmed via PM.

They had red in their eyes. Jonathan's death changed the quaint town of Sholle. A profound sense of despair and anger overcame its citizens. The change caused them to thirst for answers, clues, anything that would help them find the people who killed Jonathan. He did not harm anybody, he only helped the people. This made his death more painful - more personal. Every evening the townspeople held a meeting in the town hall. Accusations, shouts, and expletives pierced the noisy air volleyed by everyone with an uneasy disposition distrust of his neighbor.

A reveler, perhaps afflicted by some obscure brain malady, stepped into the town hall one evening, already intoxicated by his daily trips to the local Wine and Spirits store. He clumsily hobbled left and right all the way to the stage with a bottle of whiskey in hand. He shouted with the crowd, cried with the crowd, and laughed the with crowd. And then once he had finished his newly purchased his bottle he sauntered to the podium and proclaimed "I did it".

"I did it." he repeated.

By this time the crowd had quieted to near silence and an eerie air had settled. The man looked out at the crowd through his glossy eyes, his eye lids stinging from the alcohol pulsing through his blood, perplexed that the merrymaking had ended. Time stood still for the man in a brief moment of clarity he realized what he had done. His eyes widened, his pulse increased, and he began to perspire from every pore in his body.

"I didn't mean I did that," he stammered "I meant I finally finished my whiskey."

It was too late. The crowd had already descended onto the stage like a ravenous swarm of locusts landing on a grass field. They carried him out of the town hall and threw him unto the side walk. A man approached him, a broken bottle in hand.

"You die now, bastard." he stated calmy and thrust the bottle into the drunk's stomach. And with that, he died.

MusicNinja, Vanilla Townie, has been lynched Day 1!

It is now Night 1, which will end 48 hours from the time of this post. Day 2 will begin March 17, 5:00 PM Eastern Standard Time. All night actions are due by that time.
Night 1 is now over.

Silence permeated the crowd. In their rage and fury they had killed an innocent man that knew no wrong. His blood soaked the sidewalk and seeped into the sewer, the rest curdled in the air. Dismayed by their homicidal attack the crowd dispersed and returned to their homes. They shut their doors, turned out their lights, and armed themselves.

It would be a long night.

Few people slept well, instead they restlessly watched their doors with expectant eyes thinking "Am I next?". Despite the lack of dreams and fantasies, no one heard the gun shots that echoed throughout the town.

An old, quiet man woke up to pee, an unfortunate side effect of his growing age. He adjusted himself, put on his slippers and nightgown and shuffled his feet into the bathroom. Once he was done he returned to his bed and closed his eyes waiting for the next time he would have to wake up. He thought about the meeting and the death of the drunk. He thought about what he did, and didn't do. At the meeting he didn't say much. He absorbed the anarchy and stood their stoicly, determined to not be fooled by the villians who instigated this chaos.

He heard something and his eyes immediately opened. What had he heard? A footstep? A door opening? Whatever the noise it was distinct enough that he quickly rose out of his bed and armed himself with a baseball bat. He slowly walked to his door, twisted the knob, and fueled by the rush of adrenaline pumping through his veins opened the door.

No one was outside. He walked the stairs ever so slowly to make sure the boards would not creak under his meak weight. His slippers muffled the little remaining noise. He walked into his kitchen and waited for his eyes to adjust. Something stirred behind him.

A flash of light filled his house, the gun shot echo reverberating throughout the house. The old man was dead.

Internet Stranger, Vanilla Townie, killed Night 1.

Across town, a glib and talkative man tucked in his children, locked his doors, set his alarm, and kissed his wife goodnight. He had been a big proponent of finding the people who murdered the woman and Jonathan in the alley and many respected him for his dynamic personality and vigor. He read the newspaper, scouring the article about Jonathan for any sort of clue, but his efforts proved fruitless. Tired and frustrated, he turned out his light and shut his eyes.

He dreamed of many brutal and savage things. He dreamed of a triumphant victory over the murderers, dead in the parking lot of the town hall. He dreamed of a forlorn and deserted town, its citizens scattered and scared away by the murderous outsiders who now inhabited the place. He dreamed of coming home and finding his home ransacked, his family killed. He dreamed of several men entering the town hall shooting guns, killing everyone in a bloody massacre.

He suddenly awoke. He got up and turned on his lamp. His door was open, an oddity because he always shut the door to the bedroom every night. He walked out of his room and opened the doors of his children's rooms. They were sound asleep and nothing was amiss. He walked down the hallway, opening every door to make sure everything was secure. He went downstairs and checked all of the doors and the windows. Then he heard it. A crashing sound in his garage. His heart began to pound and he cursed it, fearing the sound might give away his presence. He slowly grabbed a cutting knife from a drawer in his kitchen and cautiously approached his garage door.

He touched the door knob and the door slowly swung open. He could see that his garage door was open and that his car window was smashed, tiny bits of glass covering the floor, twinkling from the street light. He flicked the switch to the turn on the light in the garage and nothing happened. His stomach sank, freezing every muscle in his body.

"This is not safe." he whispered to himself.

Instead of closing the door and calling 911 he ventured further into the dimly lit garage, careful to avoid bits of glass from cutting his feet, careful to be quiet. He eventually made it around his car only to notice a man rifling through the trunk of his car.

"Hey!" he shouted, startling the man.

"Shit!" the burglar replied, shooting the gun in desperation. He died before his body hit the floor. In that short moment before the bullet pierced his chest he thought about his life, his family he would be leaving behind, his friends at work, and that voice.

He knew that voice.

Kortul, Gunsmith, shot Night 1!

And charter, since you seem to be unfamiliar with my style of finding scum, let me educate you. I push pretty damn hard on one person at a time, and figure out whether they're scum or not based on what they've done, how they react, and how they carry themselves after my attention has moved on. It's a complicated mix of criteria that I find works wonderfully well. It's much less effective in games with multiple scum teams, but in a game this size I doubt there are multiple scum teams. In a "large" game with 20+ players this style would be almost worthless. It works pretty much invariably in newbie games though, since there are so many known quantities (the size of the scum team, what possible town power there is, etc).

tl;dr: I find that throwing shit around and seeing not where it sticks, but where it is uncomfortably shied away from (versus dodged and vehemently cursed at) is pretty effective in finding scum... at least for me. Your mileage may vary.

A man in a black coat with gray pants and a starched, collared blue shirt walked down the sidewalk glancing at his watch and looking back up at the sky. He was carrying a bouquet of roses and a new novel by his wife's favorite author. He strode silently, acknowledging the foreboding clouds to his south. and the eminent storm. Thunder cracked in the background and brief flashes of light reflected off the windows of the stores around City Hall. As a result, the people migrated from the sidewalk to the store fronts in order to avoid the rain. The man didn't have time to stop and avoid the rain. Today was his anniversary.

The man had barely enough time to cross the lawn in front of City Hall when the first droplet fell, splashing quietly on his leather shoe, gliding off as if it never landed at all. Slowly droplets plummeted to earth and peppered the sidewalk, he had very little time before he would be soaked to the bone. He adjusted his posture, placing the flowers and the book inside of his coat and quickened his pace. As he went by City Hall the doors flew open in excited commotion. Two men were punching fell down the stairs entangled in each other's arms. Shouts and cries could be heard from the onlookers inside of the City Hall until a woman screamed shocking everyone in proximity to the shriek into consciousness. They all looked at the man hunched over, now running across the lawn to avoid the rain, and they all perceived him to be hiding something in his coat. Something big. Scared, battered, and furious the two quarreling men rushed the lover. He had barely enough time to even notice the two beasts let alone react to their assault. In one big hit they knocked him to the ground, cracking his skull open on an unfortunately placed rock.

The rain was falling in sheets now, washing away the blood as it streamed out of his head. He lay there, half conscious, and looked at the sky. His vision blurred, obscuring the clouds, the trees, and the two men rifling through his coat. They picked up his book and his flowers and stared down at the men with great agony. His final thought before passing on was a picture of his mistress in a bikini at the beach.

Apparently the solace of the morning without new blood was not enough to save everyone in the town. As each day passed and the body count increased, the atmosphere in City Hall grew more tense. Not a soul could be found in the townsquare outside of the City Hall. Not one person dared to walk to the streets of Sholle after yesterday's incident. A youth typical of the rebellious mindset with piercing's punctuating his face, multicolored hair more vibrant than a rainbow, and a black and white shirt with his favorite band "Pottymouth" walked into the City Hall. His presence in the days preceding had been minimal, his contributions fairly nonexistent. He kept quiet counsel, scanning the crowd's faces for anything odd hoping he could be that one that did something different. Hoping that he could be one to find a clue linked to Jonathan's murder. He found nothing. The days passed and his mere presence intensified the animosity in the room. He was too different, too rebellious and it made people nervous.

His appearance isolated him to a corner with a bench. He sat there in solitude watching men, women, young and old, ugly and beautiful, spit saliva as they shouted at each other until their faces were red. Their emotions were running high, he noticed. At a particularly fervent and emotional juncture, he stood up, mumbled something under his breath and began to walk towards the exit pulling a chain out of his pocket. This action only exacerbated the anger in the crowd.

A man stepped foward grabbing the youth by his collar only to scream in pain clutching his hand. The youth's necklace had cut his palm. By this time the blood had entered the water. Their eyes turned to the youth, their anger focused on a central figure, on the skull toilet insignia of his shirt. He stuttered and stammered to say something, anything to prevent them from encroaching further on his rapidly dwindling personal space he had come to cherish. He watched the crowd encircle his position. Their faces of pure animosity seared into the back of his retinas. Words struggled to come out of his mouth, and when push came to shove he realized he did not want to stand out in a crowd. His heart beat slowed, his stomach dropped, his mouth filled with cotton. Before he could raise his arms in defense, a chair came crashing down on his head snapping into hundreds of jagged pen sized splinters. He looked up at his attacker, blood gushing out of the top of his skull. The blood stained the white skull on his shirt and soaked his pants. His right ear had filled with blood, making it very difficult to hear. His hair was a mixture of black and red, the colors muted by the blood. One woman picked up a splinter. A second man picked up a splinter and shouted

"Did you kill them!?"

The youth turned to the dampened, inaudible noise. Maybe it was the blood, or the chair, or something else entirely whatever the cause he didn't understand the man's shout. Fatigued by the loss of blood he stared at the crowd with a combination of perplexed and agonizing glances incapable of saying a word due to his fear and his injury.

The woman stepped forward, plunging her splinter into the fountain of blood. Next the man placed his splinter in the boy's neck. The stabbing only stopped until everyone in the crowd filled their appetite.

Hours passed until his mother came to identify the body. She rushed through the grand oak doors, past the crowd, and fell onto his body. She clutched his head to her breasts. A constant stream of tears only ebbed by the mother's visceral cries and damnations of God fell on the boy.

"He was a good kid!" she moaned with the full capacity of her lungs. "He was just different!"

After several minutes her tear ducts finally dried and the grief stricken mother faced the crowd with swollen, red eyes.

"When will this stop?"

Night 3 ends Wednesday April 4, 2012 at 10:00 PM Eastern Standard Time.

A cold front had moved over the town of Sholle, casting grey shadows on the inhabitants and blowing cool breezes of wind, ruffling leaves from the trees. The noise from the trees and the wind shook shutters, rattled doors, and screamed against tightly closed windows. The noise muffled all but the loudest sounds of the night. Rats running through the field did not hear the distinctive flapping of wings from the owls. The cats in the alley behind City Hall could not locate any vermin to gorge themselves.

Clouds floated quietly and quickly in the night sky, often obscuring the moonlight leaving only street lamps to reliably brighten the town. A lowly night guard had just finished his night shift and was walking home wearing his thick brown comforted by the warm fleece interior. He was largely untouched by the town's vehement and irrational blood lust because he seldom had the time to go to City Hall on account of his job. He stopped in front of a storefront to examine his appearance in the crisp night air. His eyes looked shrunken compared to the puffy bags popping up from his cheek. His hair waving in the wind looked like a brown extension of his coat. His lips were cracked, dried out by the constant breeze. He looked horrible in every way. His late nights and long hours had sapped any vitality from the his bones. Still he hoped someday soon he would be promoted and finally leave the grasp of his the dreaded night shifts.

He walked on further, slowly, letting the cool air fill his lungs and leave his body. This type of weather was his favorite weather. He had lived in tropical, arid, and cold places, but never in neutrally warm and neutrally cold area. He was glad he was the only one enjoying the breeze, selfishly trying to draw in as much of the cold air as his lungs would allow.

He stood their, hands in his coat pockets, deeply breathing in the air slowly exhaling it after his lungs screamed for release. But like the mouse ,and the cat, he could faintly hear a noise. Had it not been windy, had he not stopped to talk in all of the fresh air he could, perhaps he would be alive now. Perhaps if he had participated in the daily City Hall meetings he could have stopped this murderous spree. All of this was now behind him as he fell onto the cold pavement and the shadowy figure walked to the opposite side of the street. He watched his killer cross under the streetlight, faintly making out his appearance. He tried to utter a word, but no sound, if he made a sound, could be heard. His legs wouldn't move and his back ached in severe pain. The wind he was so fond over failed to enter his nose for his nose was bleeding from the fall. He chose to breathe through his mouth hoping that someone heard the gunshot, hoping that someone would come to his rescue. Each time he took a breath his lungs and his back felt like they were on fire. Still he persisted, hoping someone would help him.

The sun began to set after a long and ardous day of deliberation. All of pressure the town felt built up under the extreme force of fear. How many days did they have left before their lively hood's would be destroyed? How many more bodies would it take to stop the criminals who started this whole bloody ordeal? Too many days had passed filled with red herrings and erroneous thinking, the town was stuck in a rut with seemingly no way to escape. They were no better off than the day after Jonathan's death.

Many promised vengeance for Jonathan, promising his family to find the culprits, but those promises would not be filled.

One man boldly stood up and shouted obscenities at the speaker and began to leave City Hall. At the door the entire audience rose in unison, staring at the man. He looked back and shouted "Fuck off, I'm the Mayor." before leaving through the giant wooden doors that had become a symbol of death for the townspeople. He walked down the stone staircase, buttoned his jacket, put on his hat staring at the low hanging sun. He planned to quit the next day, for the town no longer expressed his ethical desires, or the principles he had set since becoming mayor. Wasn't he partly to blame for this mob mentality? As mayor he did nothing. Surely he would have remorse.

The crowd was now walking out of City Hall into the soft orange and yellow light. The clouds closest to the setting sun adopted a red trim, those farther away appeared as balls of pink. They looked at each other dismayed at their failures, saddened by their murderous acts, and frustrated at their ineptness. They looked at the town, now mostly empty. People seldom walked or left their houses for that matter. Those not involved in the killings waited in their homes patiently, hoping to ride out the storm, little did they know that the eye was now passing over.

A man sat crouched a storefront's door across the street. He had dark hair, tan skin, and was listening to the radio while fiddling with the locked door. He went to his truck, turning the volume up, and returning with something silver. His liscense plate was from a foreign locality. He clearly was not from around these parts.

Slowly, one by one the crowd approached the man, casting a shadow on the door knob. In frustration he looked up and noticed the mass of people.

"Hello .. uh, foks. What can I .. uh.. do for ya?" he stated casually.

"What are you doing?" one woman responded.

"Oh this? I'm .. uh ... fixing a lock."

"You're not from around here are you, pal?" a disgruntled man said, taking of his cap.

"No, .. uh sir. I'm .. uh locksmith. Someone called me from .. uh this store. Said they .. uh needed help since .. uh the other locksmith was busy."

"The other locksmith?" the man with the hat replied.

"Uh... ya."

"Do you know what has been going on around here lately?"

"Uh-"

"You haven't heard about the murders?" the woman added

"No, I-"

"You don't know about the mob?" the man said as he approached, reaching into his pocket

"Mob? What mob?"

"This mob." he said coldy

"No, I've only been in town for a couple of days I didn't have the right parts to fix this door." the locksmith said in a quivering voice.

"Convenient, since that was the time when these murders started."

"What? You don't seriously think I am the one you're after?"

"That's exactly what I think!" the man shouted lunging forward with a screw driver he took from the man's truck.

Screams erupted from the crowd prompting the Mayor to run to the store. "What in the hell was going on?" he thought. He pushed his way through the crowd to see the locksmith fighting off the man with the screw driver. The locksmith's ear was bleeding and a piece of his lobe was missing. The blood trickled down the leftside of his neck and onto his blue shirt and denim pants.

"What is the matter with you people!?" the mayor inquired, ending the conflict immediately.

"Hasn't enough blood been shed? Haven't enough people paid with their lives? Haven't enough innocent people been persecuted by your thirst for blood?"

An unknown voice rose out from the crowd, distinguished from the rest. "No" it replied. The mayor turned in horror at the thought of this proclamation only to stare down the barrel of a hand gun. Releasing the trigger, the voice replied "This town is ours."

Congratulations to the Mafia!

The Mafia played well enough so that they never lost a member, but I don't know how much of that can be attributed to their own play and not the town's unfortunate play.

MusicNinja's play really hurt the town early on and contributed a lot to the loss of town motivation. It allowed the scum to easily skirt by Day 1 without leaving too much in their wake and their lucky kill on Night 1 hurt the town even more. That cycle in its whole is the main reason why the town lost. If it had been one or the other, I think there could have been room for rebound but that cycle just sapped the energy.

The newbies of this game played really well and I hope you all continue to play on MafiaScum despite this game. You all are good players and I am sure you will only continue to grow in skill.

Kdowns played well preventing kills, and if he had gone with his Mastin suspicion he would have left two guppie scum by themselves which could have turned out interesting.

Charter, why did you decide to kill Pieceofpecanpie instead of Vijay that night? Why did you kill IS over Vijay for his posts about the Music wagon?

All three Mafia dodged suspicion because the town was so willing to pile onto other wagons which allowed the Mafia to utilize their voting bloc well in my opinion. Mastin's claim of JoAT was in my opinion a high risk claim as there was no real reason why town should have a JoAT since no Mafia had flipped yet. UberNinja's vote hopping was scummy and opportunistic from my point of view, but no one seemed to bat an eye.

The pieceofpecanpie lynch was in my opinion the worst of the lynches as the town completely disregarded the fact that he could have been a victim of a shot. I was hoping with Kdown's protection that the town would be able to last for one more day and lynch a scum member, but wishful thinking.

I hope you all had fun, but from the activity and motivation I don't think you guys did . While I technically only needed to send out one prod, there were instances that slipped between the cracks and I am thankful to all of you. It is nice not having to be on someone's case about activity.

MusicNinja barely getting by without a modkill put me in a suspenseful situation early on, I am just glad he didn't try to outright break the rule for the sake of the game but in the end it wouldn't have mattered. His actions have shown me that I need to remove that rule, though.

What did you guys think? Did you like the flavor? Did you like the setup? Did you like me modding?

I tried to give you guys a votecount everday, but there were some days when I couldn't get to the computer and I am sorry for that.

Did you guys dislike 48H nights? If enough people expressed interest in 72H I would have changed it, but I didn't receive any PMs from people saying they wanted slower nights. Frankly, I was hoping it would keep momentum up.

All in all I think the set-up was balanced as I had designed it to be less intrusive than other games, but still retaining power. Do you all think it was balanced?
